contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem as being without protection, as if it were a vulnerable widow. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

This speaks of Zion's princes having nothing to eat like deer that cannot find grass to eat. Alternate translation: "Her princes are starving, they are like deer that cannot find grass to eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Her princes have become like deer that cannot find pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem being scorned in the same way that a woman is scorned when she is unclean. According to the law of Moses, a woman was considered unclean during her monthly bleeding. Alternate translation: "Jerusalem's sins have made her filthy and unclean, and therefore she was unacceptable before God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Jerusalem sinned greatly, therefore, she has become scorned as something that is filthy

contextId.occurrenceNote: A soldier has to bend his bow in order to shoot an arrow from it. This speaks of the Lord preparing to attack Israel as if he were an enemy about to shoot them with a bow and arrow. Alternate translation: "He has prepared to kill us, like an enemy who has made his bow ready to shoot us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like an enemy he has bent his bow toward us, with his right is ready to shoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the tabernacle being easily destroyed, as if it were a garden hut. The Lord caused Israel's enemies to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. Alternate translation: "He has caused their enemies to attack his tabernacle as easily as if it were a garden hut" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He has attacked his tabernacle like a garden hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the children fainting from hunger and thirst in the same way that a wounded man faints. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as they faint like a wounded man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem's great suffering as if it were as terrible as the sea is great. Alternate translation: "Your suffering is as terrible as the sea is large" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Your wound is as great as the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: "as if they were coming to a feast." This speaks of how Yahweh summoned his enemies as if he were inviting them to a feast. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as you would call the people to a feast day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of God being ready to cause him to suffer more, as if God were a wild animal waiting to attack him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He is like a bear waiting to ambush me, a lion in hiding

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are compared to filthy scum and refuse. Possible meanings are 1) God has caused the nations to think of his people as worthless. Alternate translation: "You have made the nations think of us as scum and garbage" or 2) God's forcing his people to live among the nations is like throwing them away as garbage. Alternate translation: "You have thrown us away like filthy garbage among the nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You have made us like filthy scum and refuse among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people in Jerusalem are compared to ostriches because they are cruel to their children. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the daughter of my people ... like the ostriches in the desert

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their dry skin is compared to dry wood. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: it has become as dry as wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author compares the speed of their pursuers to the speed of eagles flying. Eagles fly very quickly to catch other animals. Alternate translation: "Those who were chasing us were faster than eagles" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Our pursuers were swifter than the eagles in the sky

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the peoples' bodies being hot and feverish as if their skin was as hot as an oven. The people have fever because of their hunger. Alternate translation: "Our skin has become hot like an oven, and we have a very high fever because we are extremely hungry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Our skin has grown as hot as an oven because of the burning heat of hunger
